Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Innovative Molecular Methods for Low Cost DNA Barcoding of Tropical Arthropods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Preservation of biodiversity is essential to an ecosystem?s ability to withstand disturbances like climate change and to provide services to human society. Traditional methods of measuring insect and other arthropod diversity are time consuming and expensive which impedes creation of effective conservation policies. In collaboration with Dr. Rudolf Meier at the National University of Singapore, this project will improve and share the knowledge of new techniques developed in the Meier lab for generating DNA barcodes for insect identification. DNA barcodes are a specific short sequence of DNA which can be used to identify an organism, much like how the barcode on the back of a cereal box is scanned at a grocery store. Paired with the researcher?s larger thesis project, this work will improve biodiversity evaluation and monitoring methods while uncovering relationships in arthropod forest communities.

This project will use new direct PCR protocols and next-generation sequencing methods to DNA barcode thousands of insect specimens. A biodiversity assessment and comparison between the forests of Kentucky (United States) and French Guiana using metabarcoding is underway. Groups of interest, including parasitoids and caterpillars, as well as representatives of all arthropod orders present will be removed from the metabarcoded samples for use as voucher specimens. To evaluate the metabarcoding process and discover parasitoid-host relationships, DNA barcodes linked to these specimens will be generated using a low cost method developed by Rudolf Meier's lab. The proportion of voucher specimen sequences found within the metabarcoding sequence datasets will allow for the adjustment of diversity estimates to account for biases in the sequencing process. Direct PCR and next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods can produce barcodes at less than $1 per specimen but require training and experience to perform successfully and consistently. Dr. Meier?s protocols were designed for use with Diptera and will be optimized for use with hymenopteran parasitoids. The data generated during this project will be used to compare tropical and temperate arthropod biodiversity, to compare morphological and molecular identification techniques, and discover new parasitoid-host relationships.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are currently in the midst of earth’s 6th mass extinction. As the majority of animals are arthropods, the majority of extinctions occurring are among this group. Since most arthropods, especially tropical species, are largely unknown, we are unable quantify the value of the biodiversity we are losing or work effectively to save it. However, new molecular technologies are emerging that can be harnessed to address this alarming problem. Led by Prof. Rudolf Meier, the laboratory for Evolutionary Biology at The National University of Singapore is pioneering the use of next-generation sequencing (NGS) to effectively document massive numbers of species at an unprecedented rate.

The purpose of this project was for the PI to work in Meier’s evolutionary biology lab in Singapore to receive training in his novel, and largely unpublished, techniques for generating low-cost arthropod DNA barcodes. DNA barcodes for animals are a small section of the COI gene found in mitochondria. Barcodes can be compared between specimens to help determine whether they are the same species, or queried against a library of sequences to provide an identification. Specimens of parasitoid insects in the wasp families Braconidae, Ichneumonidae, and Chalcididae, and the fly family Tachinidae were collected using Malaise traps from forests in temperate Kentucky and tropical French Guiana. Direct PCR techniques developed for use on flies and ants were successfully adapted to work with the wasps. As long as the specimens are properly preserved, this method eliminates the need to perform DNA extractions prior to PCR and sequencing, saving much time and money. Direct PCR, along with the use of tagged primers and NGS platforms, brought the cost of DNA barcodes generated during this project down to about $0.30 each. Just under 200 specimens could be processed by one worker per day.

1614 of the 1900 specimens barcoded produced successful sequences. Similarities between the sequences can be used to group them into preliminary species, called molecular operational taxonomic units, or MOTUs. 715 MOTUs were discovered in this project. There was no overlap between the MOTUs from the two different sites. The tropical site had higher species diversity than the temperate, as one would expect. Braconids were more prevalent than Ichneumonids in the tropical site, while the opposite was true in the temperate site. When queried against the DNA libraries in GenBank, most of the tropical specimens did not have matches greater than 90% similarity, and almost no high percent matches identified to the species level. Most of the temperate specimens had a match above 98% similarity in the library and one fifth of those were identified to the species level. As the libraries grow and more identified sequences are added to them the power to identify unknown sequences, like those from this project, will improve. Additional analysis is still underway, including morphological identification of the specimens to genus level and comparison of feeding guild differences between the two sites. The new techniques developed and shared over the course of this project will accelerate biodiversity discovery and research, improving conservation and our knowledge of the natural world.
